Anthony B. sells herbal medicine. He is a single parent of 2 children. His income is not enough to meet the financial needs of the family, so he wants to increase production and sale, but he lacks capital.

He is asking for $525 to buy materials for production.

loans.use: To buy materials for production.

loans.name: Kokoè

texts.fr:
Born March 12th, 1973 in Vogan village of VO prefecture, Mrs. Kokoè T. K. is married and the mother of three children. She sells jewelry and fabric in the Agoè neighborhood; she has been doing business since June 2004. She buys jewelry from Cotonou, Benin and fabric from the main market in Lomé. This is the first loan she is seeking, for 500,000 francs CFA and it will allow her to buy 40 pairs of earrings, 20 bracelets, and 40 necklaces. Her goal in borrowing this loan is to expand her display in order to attract more customers. 
Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.
Née le 12 mars 1973 à vogan dans la préfecture de VO, Madame T. K. Kokoè est mariée et mère de trois (3) enfants. Elle exerce le commerce de bijoux et de pagnes dans le quartier d’Agoè. Elle a démarré ce commerce depuis juin 2004. Elle achète les bijoux de Cotonou au Bénin et les pagnes au grand marché de Lomé. Le premier crédit d’un montant de 500.000FCFA qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter quarante (40)  boucles d’oreilles, vingt (20) gomettes et quarante (40) colliers. Son objectif, en prenant ce crédit est  d’agrandir son étalage afin de pouvoir attirer plus de clients.

loans.use: Jewelry retail

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.es:
Alejandra is divorced and has three small children. Because of the pension Alejandra receives, her children are able to attend elementary school. But the pension isn’t enough to cover some of the children’s costs, such as food, school fees, sickness, etc. Three years ago Alejandra decided to start a business and began selling lightly used clothing, which she buys in bundles. Her business has been profitable.

Alejandra needs a loan of $600, which she will pay back in 6 months, to remodel her house and convert one of its rooms into a shop. This way she’ll have more space to display the clothes she sells. She also plans to buy shelves to display these clothes. With your support Alejandra can expand her business.

Translated by Todd M. Anderson, Kiva volunteer

Alejandra es divorciada y tiene 3 hijos pequeños que cursan la primaria debido a que la pension que recibe es muy poca y no es suficiente para mantener los gastos de los niños como: de alimentacion, gastos escolares, enfermedades, etc., hace tres años ella decidio emprender un negocio, empezo con la venta de ropa seminueva la cual compra por pacas, y le ha generado buenos ingresos.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $600 que pagara en 6 meses ya que desea remodelar su casa y convertir en local una de las recamaras para asi tener mayor esapcio para la exhibion de la ropa, ademas de comprar algunos estantes para lo mismo. Con tu apoyo Alejandra podra hacer crecer su negocio.

loans.use: Remodel and buy shelves

loans.name: Tainess

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 27 year-old Tainess K..  She is married, and has one child, aged one. She has two dependents who live with her because they are orphans.  In 2007, Tainess established her timber selling business. Working six days a week, and five to eight hours a day, she earns about US $70 every month from this business. Tainess requires a loan in order to buy additional stocks of timber in bulk. She thanks you for your support.  

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks of timber in bulk.

loans.name: Beatrice Musisi‘S Group

texts.en:
Beatrice works five days a week and operates a salon. She buys her merchandise from Kampala city centre. She buys all types of goods from both retail and wholesale and uses public transport to transport her merchandise from Kampala to her salon/shop in Bwaise. She makes the trip twice a week. Her customers are women in her community and those on the move.

Her challenges include paying high taxes, high rental charges, and transport costs. Flooding is a problem during the rainy season as the area where she is operating is prone to floods, which destroys her merchandise. It was once a wetland. Another challenge is that of her business being seasonal. During periods when there is low demand for salons, she switches to selling cereals and legumes, mainly dried beans. She has been operating this business for the last 10 years and was inspired by the way women were moving long distances looking for salons. She has been able to improve her standards of living, provide her family with three meals daily. Her main inspiration is owning a permanent home to operate from and also seeing her business progressing.

Beatrice is the leader of a 4-member group. She is 28 years old and married with 2 children. They are 7 and 2 years old. The one aged seven years is in school. She rents a three-room house in which she lives with 5 people. There is no piped water and electricity. She resides and works in a semi-urban and slum area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala.

loans.use: To purchase more beans

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap D., 40, and her husband, Mr. Cheng-ean Hean, 52, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.  They were married in 1984 and have seven children: two sons and five daughters. Two of their children are construction workers, and two other children are silk weavers. Three children study at the local school.

Mrs. Sopheap has been a silk weaver for 25 years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband raises cows at home.

Sopheap is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase silk materials for her and her children's weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving.

loans.name: Maria Verónica

texts.es: Esta señora  desde temprana edad se dedica a trabajar en calzado, ella se mantiene al frente del taller y  su esposo se encarga de la comercialización del calzado que oferta en el mercado municipal de Masaya. El taller cuenta con 6 trabajadores a tiempo completo. Tiene dos hijos que asisten a clases, ella a demás de atender el taller atiende los quehaceres de la casa  Ella espera  que adim le pueda otorgar  créditos mayores que le permitan adquirir mayor cantidad de materia prima ya que cuenta con mucha clientela. Su mayor sueño es de  mejorar su nivel de vida, remodelar su casa y darles una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
From an early age, this woman worked on shoes. She maintains the front of the workshop, and her husband is in charge of marketing the shoes that are sold in the city market in Masaya. The workshop has 6 full-time workers. She has two children that are studying. In addition to taking care of the workshop, she also takes care of the housework. She hopes that Adim can offer her bigger loans that will allow her to buy more raw materials, since her has many clients. Her biggest dream is to improve her level in life, remodel her house, and give a good education to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Kit

texts.en:
Mrs. Kit M., 53, and her husband were married in 1979 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. Two of her children are married and live outside the family home, two others are silk weavers, one works in a garment factory, and one is a student in grade nine. The family lives in a small village near the Mekong River about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Kit has been a silk weaver since 1970; she learned the skill from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband cannot work because he has a serious illness.

Kit is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose Z. sells vegetables and is requesting a loan to purchase more vegetables. Rose is 28 years old and married. Her husband is a policeman. She has three children and they all go to school. With the extra profits generated from her loan, she hopes to be able to continue to send her children to school.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Na

texts.en: Mrs. Na C. was born in 1980 and she now lives in Takol village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a farmer who cultivates rice on a 1 hectare plot of land. She is a 28 year old widow with one child who is attends the local school. Although she works hard, she still does not earn sufficient income to support the family. They also live in an old house that is in poor condition. In order to improve these conditions, Mrs. Na C. decided to request a loan to add to her savings and build a new house for her family. She hopes to provide a better life for her family with this new loan.

loans.use: requests a loan to add to her saving and build a new house for her family.

loans.name: Hasfa Nakku ‘S Group

texts.en:
Hasfa is the leader of a four member group. She is a 35 year old mother of four children who are between the ages for five and eleven. All her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in a rented two-roomed house in which four people stay. They have electricity and piped water at home and the family gets three meals a day. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.

Hasfa sells sugar cane in Kalerwe market and works seven days a week. She buys the sugar cane from Kawolo, one of the villages where sugar cane is mostly grown. She uses private means to go to and from Kawolo. She sells both on retail and wholesale to an average of 15 customers a day and has been in this business for 10 years. Hasfa is servicing her fourteenth loan, working all along with the same groupmates. She wants to use this loan to start buying a full lorry of sugar canes.

loans.use: To start buying a full lorry of sugar canes to sell.

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
For the past three years, Mwajuma has been running a small store in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar where she sells charcoal and firewood. She belongs to Uvivu si kazi loan group (group code 2005).  She currently realizes an average monthly profit of $80. Every day she works at her place of business for 14 hours. She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and firewood. She is hoping that this loan will help her increase her profits and expand her business. 

Mwajuma is 26 years old and married. She has four children, ages 12 years, 7years, 6 years, and 1 month.

loans.use: To buy charcoal and firewood for resale.

loans.name: Felibretina

texts.es:
Felibretina es socia del Bancomunal  Santa Rosa de Villa.
Felibretina es conviviente, tiene 29 años  un hijo de ocho años que va a la escuela estatal.
Empezó a trabajar desde los 10 años en un mercado, de  joven salió embarazada y no pudo estudiar,  nuevamente se dedico a vender en un mercado; hace dos años puso una bodega en su casa.
Necesita un préstamo de 1800 soles, para agrandar su tienda falta construir un pedazo, y comprar mercadería, arroz leche, aceite.
El sueño de Felibretina es poner un mini marque, y alquilar un local.
texts.en:
Felibretina is a member of the Santa Rosa de Villa Community Bank. Felibretina lives with her partner, is 29 years old, and has an eight year old son who attends the state school. She began working at the age of 10 in a market, became pregnant at a young age, and was not able to study. She recently began working in the market, and two years ago installed a small grocery story in her home. She needs a loan of 1800 soles to enlarge her store, as there is still a portion to build, and to buy merchandise like rice, milk, and oil. Felibretina's dream is to put up a small awning and rent another premises.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She needs a loan of 1800 soles to enlarge her store and build another part, and to buy merchandise like rice, milk, and oil.

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatou N. est une commerçante veuve qui habite au quartier SOM à Thiès. Depuis 1998 elle vend des schandwich le soir et le matin et des petits déjeuners devant chez elle. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son activité qui consiste à acheter de la farine, des œufs, de l’huile, du sucre etc., et également d’une machine à coudre pour confectionner des pagnes. Les revenues lui permettent de se nourrir et de payer les depenses de la maison.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatou N. is a widowed businesswoman who lives in the SOM neighborhood in Thiès. Since 1998, she has been selling sandwiches in the evening and breakfasts in the morning, outside her house. She is requesting this loan to bolster her little business, that is, to buy flour, eggs, oil, sugar, etc., and also to buy a sewing machine to sew "pagnes" (brightly printed African cloth used as sarongs). The income will allow her to feed herself and pay household expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of flour, eggs, oil, and sugar

loans.name: Inobatchon

texts.ru:
Инобатчон женщина 25 лет, замужем , имеет двоих детей. Она занимается  бизнесом продажи косметики. Товар привозит с Истаравшана, а также её поставляют поставщики. Инобатчон  имеет одну дочь и сына, они учатся в лицее- гимназии города Худжанда.
Её муж работает мастером по ремонту автомобилей. Он хорошо зарабатывал, но сейчас поток клиентов уменьшился, и его доход значительно, недостаточен для проживания семьи. Поэтому, Инобатчон хочет в кредит увеличить свой оборотный капитал, бизнес
texts.en:
Inobatchon is a 25 year old woman, she is married and has two children. She is in the business of selling cosmetic products. She buys the merchandise in Istaravshan and also from her suppliers. Inobatchon has one daughter and one son, they are studying at the lyceum-grammar school in the town of Khudjand. Her husband works as an auto repairman. He was making good money, but at this time he does not have so many customers and his income is noticeably not enough to sustain the family. This is why Inobatchon wants to use the loan to increase her business working capital.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Maendeleo 'a' Group

texts.en:
Jane is 36 years old, married, and has six children: ages 15, 12, 9, 6, and 2. Jane has been a fish seller in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for many years. She currently earns very little monthly profit. Every day she works at her business for twelve hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more fish for resale in order to expand her business. She is hoping that through this loan her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Jane will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member Nandiwe. Nandiwe has her own small business selling milk in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more fish for resale.

loans.name: Rafonzel

texts.en: Rafonzel D. is a single resident of Dapitan City, Zamboanga del Norte. She has been a member of Paglaum Coop for almost two years and has had four loans. She operates an eatery beside the sea port.  Her last loan was used to purchase more stocks of meat, fish, spices and other ingredients for her business, hoping to alleviate her life of hard work.

loans.use: Purchase meat, fish and spices for eatery

loans.name: Juan Antonio

texts.es:
Juan Antonio G. vive en el departamento de Ahuachapán. Juan tiene 65 años de edad vive con su pareja y sus tres hijos. Juan se dedica principalmente a la venta de ropa, su mecánica de trabajo es de manera ambulante  el visita todos los pueblos de sus alrededores en su carro, donde lleva toda la mercadería, Juan obtiene ganancias de 50% en la mercadería que el vende. Ademas de tener este negocio, por ser persona muy trabajadora, también tiene una tienda, muy surtida de artículos de primera necesidad.

Juan solicita este crédito para comprar más mercadería para su negocio.
texts.en:
Juan Antonio G. lives in the Ahuachapan department. Juan is 65 years old and lives with his spouse and three children. Juan makes a living primarily from selling clothing as a street vendor. He visits the surrounding towns in his car, where he has all his merchandise. Juan makes a 50% profit on all his sales. In addition to this business, since he is a very hard working person, he also has a store, which is well stocked with basic goods. Juan is requesting this loan to be able to purchase more merchandise for his business.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Rodney

texts.en:
Rodney B. owns and operates a motorcycle transport business providing service to local community members. He is 25 years old and married. He is from the village of Kinangay Sur, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Rodney has been in this business for over one year and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rodney joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Rodney is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be his first loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand a motorcycle transport business

loans.name: Math

texts.en:
Math M. has been a local vendor for thirty years and lives with other family members in a medium-sized wooden house located in Phnom Penh, the capital. Presently, she owns a motorcycle which she uses to pick up metal cooking tools to sell door-to-door around her community. Her husband is a local construction foreman.

This couple, pictured above, is blessed with four children who are studying in the local secondary school. Because of the lack of capital to grow her business, Math M. has decided to seek a $500 loan in order to buy pots, pans, and other kitchen equipment to sell.

loans.use: To buy pots, pans, and other kitchen equipment to sell

loans.name: Kobada 3 De (Kobada Nokabougou) Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe KOBADA 3 sont des femmes mariées qui ont en moyenne 49 ans, 7 enfants et  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames dans le village de NOKABOUGOU,  commune de Tingolé, sous préfecture de FANA, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles sont en  partenariat avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’avoir un appui financier pour exercer leurs activités hivernales qui sont entre autres la culture du sorgho de l’arachide et du haricot. Elles sont à leur cinquième expérience avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été remboursés correctement.
Ce  prêt sera utilisé pour acheter de l’engrais, de l’herbicide, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de sarclage et de labour pour entretenir 21 hectares.
Une partie de leur production est auto consommée et l’autre partie est vendue sur les marchés de Tingolé, Marka-Coungo et Fana, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40 000FCFA après la campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group KOBADA 3 are married women who average 49 years of age and 7 children. These women live for the most part in polygamous families in the village of NOKABOUGOU, in the community of Tingolé, sub-prefecture of FANA, (2nd administrative region of Mali). They are in a partnership with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of obtaining financial support to carry out their winter-time work, which includes growing sorghum, peanuts, and beans. They are on their fifth experience with the institution. The past loans were correctly repaid. This new loan will be used to buy fertilizer, herbicide, and minor farm supplies and equipment and will cover the cost of weeding and labor for maintaining 21 hectares. A portion of their production is for their own consumption. The other portion is sold to customers composed of men and women at the marketplaces of Tingolé, Marka-Coungo, and Fana. The group members plan on realizing an average profit of 40,000 francs CFA after the planting campaign.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, fertilizer, herbicide, weeding, and minor farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Grandensio's Group

texts.en:
N. Grandensia is the leader of her lending group in Seguku. She is 50 years old and married. She has 2 dependents and  she helps to take care of 7 orphans. All of the children go to school. 

She is a businesswoman who sells charcoal and matooke at the Seguku Trading Centre. Although the competition is stiff, she is able to make 30,000/= (Ugandan shillings) in profits each week. Her loans have enabled her to own a house for her family. In the future, she plans to expand her business further because her family grows by the day. Grandensia says that, although she has two main businesses, she also sells other produce, such  as cassava, irish potatoes, and cabbage. She needs a loan to help restock her business with a variety of food.

loans.use: To buy more matooke and charcoal for her business

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick is 35 years old and a father of four who lives and operates his food kiosk business in Mukuru, Nairobi, Kenya. Patrick has requested a loan of Ksh 60,000 in order to add to his stock of maize flour, wheat flour, oil and beans. He has been in this business for the last five years. Patrick hopes to own a hotel in Nairobi one day and to make a good foundation for his family. He describes himself as diligent and faithful. About Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To add to his stock

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina is a responsible mother to her four children. She is married to Santiago, a farmer. Their eldest son, Florentino, is 22 years old. He graduated from college and is now working as a dental technician in Manila. Their second child, Harold, age 19, is currently studying to be a dental technician in Manila. Next is Myrna, age 16 and Epifanio, age 12, both of whom are studying in high school. Lina hopes that all her children finish their studies because she believes that their achievements in life are also achievements for their parents who supported them all the way.  

Lina is requesting a loan of PHP 4,000 from Kiva. She will use the loan to improve her rice business. She sells rice and vegetables three times a week in the market. When not in the market, she tries to sell her vegetables in their village through house-to-house vending. She hopes that, with patience, she can send all her children to college and attain their dream, which is to finish their studies and look for jobs. She is glad that her husband also works hard as a farmer. They strive to give their children a bright future.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more used clothes in bulk

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Edwin D. is 30 years old and owns and manages a small rice field in Kapatungan, Trento, Agusan del Sur. He has spent the majority of his time on the farm and is able to grow crops like rice to support his family. As a father, it’s always a challenge for him to provide all the needs for their home. He wants to do well in rice farming to be able to save money and send all his five children to school until they reach college.

He desires to increase the usual size of his harvest. To accomplish this, he would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. He will use the loan to fund his farm to buy farming necessities in order to have an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Cresencia

texts.en:
Cresencia would like to borrow Php 8,000 from KIVA lenders to pursue her livestock business. She plans to purchase native chickens to raise as an additional source of income. She hopes to further expand her business and purchase more poultry feed for her native chickens. With this loan, she also hopes to start a hog-raising business.

Cresencia is 55 years old and is married to Andy M., a company truck driver. They are blessed with three children, one of whom is married. They live happily in Calaocan, Cabatuan, Isabela with their grandson. Cresencia hopes that, with her loan, she can improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy chickens and chicken feed and start a hog-raising business

loans.name: Raed

texts.en:
Raed is married with four children.  He has been working as a taxi driver for a long time as he left school before finishing his high school.  He was not a hard working student, even hough his father was the principle, because he always preferred the freedom of working. 

Raed owns a van that works between Hebron, Beit Ummar village, and Bethlehem.  His work is going very well, last year he bought a new van in exchange for the old van and all his savings. Since he spent his savings to buy the new van, Raed is requesting a loan from FATEN for $1500 US to pay insurance and registration fees.  He must pay these to be able to register the new van, which is required before he can use it for work.

Raed appears in the picture next to his van.

loans.use: Registration & insurance fees

loans.name: Justus Kamande

texts.en:
Justus is 50 years old and married to Nelius Wambui. They have four sons and one daughter. He has been doing coffee farming for the past 29 years and also he operates a green grocery stall as his other source of income.

Justus was introduced to Kadet through marketing outreach and he has no previous credit history with any other MFI. He has applied for a loan which he is planning to use to expand and venture into different farming activities like platting maize, French beans and French peas.

He intends to buy dairy cattle with this the extra profit he generates from the farm produce and green grocery. His future hope and dream is to export his farm produce to other countries. He describes himself as a hardworking man.

loans.use: To expand farming by planting new crops like french beans and peas

loans.name: Elizabet

texts.es:
Elizabet tiene 42 años, vive muy contenta al lado de su esposo Clemente, de 44 años; juntos tienen 5 hijos, pero solo viven con 4 de ellos; Joel de 22, Isabel de 18, Nelida de 16 y Paúl de 11 años.

Su día empieza desde muy temprano, pues se despierta con muchos ánimos de trabajar en sus tierras, en la siembra de papa, con la ayuda de su esposo y sus hijos. Este trabajo es muy sacrificado, ya que la siembra requiere constante atención y ella lo sabe, es por eso que se preocupa por la futura cosecha, ya que será el sustento de toda su familia por una larga temporada. 
La agricultura en la sierra del Perú es una actividad que se transmite de generación en generación y así lo aprendió Elizabet, quien empezó a trabajar desde muy joven y hoy la motiva el hecho de sacar a su familia adelante. Al finalizar la cosecha ella vende toda su producción de a los comerciantes mayoristas a un buen precio.
Elizabet se ha proyecta al futuro y le gustaría sembrar en mayor cantidad, no sólo papa, sino también otros productos.

Este es el sexto préstamo que tiene con MFP y está segura de cumplir con cada uno de sus pagos, ya que le gusta ser cumplida y responsable para no quedar mal con nadie, ni con su banco comunal, donde sus compañeros también son personas trabajadoras como ella. El dinero que ahora solicita lo invertirá la compra de abono y fertilizantes para asegurar sus tierras ante las plagas y para que su cosecha sea muy fructífera.
texts.en:
Elizabet is 42 years old and lives happily with her husband, Clemente (44). Together, they have five children, four of whom live with them: Joel (22), Isabel (18), Nelida (16) and Paúl (11). Her day begins early, as she wakes up eager to work her land planting potatoes with the help of her husband and her children. The work Elizabet does is difficult as the harvest requires constant attention. She knows this and is constantly worried about future harvests since they will be the sustenance of her family for the season. Agriculture techniques in the sierras of Peru are passed down from generation to generation. This is how Elizabet learned to work the land at a young age. Today, her motivation is providing a future for her family. At the end of the harvest, she sells everything at a good price to wholesalers. Looking to the future, Elizabet would like to sow and harvest in larger quantities, and not only potatoes but other produce as well. This is Elizabet's sixth loan with Kiva partner MFP and she is confident she will make her payments timely since she is responsible and does not want to lose face with anyone or with her community bank and its members, hardworking people like her. With the loan, she will buy fertilizers and pesticides to protect her land from pests and ensure a fruitful harvest.

Translated from Spanish by Violeta Rubiani, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Siua

texts.en:
Siua L. is 34 and single with no children.  She owns a business venture,which is poultry.  Siua has 4 years of experience in this business.  Siua needs a loan of WST $750.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 160 tala or US $67 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Siua joined SPBD.  This is her 2nd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Siua's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Siua L. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.2 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.22 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.3 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated. For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purcahse chicken food and a fence to protect the chicken

loans.name: Anipa's Group

texts.en: Anipa is the leader of this group. Anipa is 40. She has a big family that consists of her, her husband and four children. Anipa lives in the city of Karabalta, which is 60 kilometers to the west of Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan. One of the main life priorities for Anipa has been to give all her children a proper education so that they have more favorable opportunities in their lives. To provide it, they saved their earnings and invested in purchasing a calf. Gradually, they increased the total population of livestock and began selling milk. Now, Anipa can boast about what a good household she and her husband together operate. Their eldest daughter has become a schoolteacher herself, and she is just 20. Two other children are still attending a secondary school. The little son is just 5 and stays at home by Anipa’s side. Raising livestock has been the main source of income for Anipa and her family for 25 years. And due to it, Anipa has been successfully raising her children and satisfying her daily needs. Recently, Anipa has applied for this loan. The reason for that is that for the rest of the winter season, Anipa urgently needs coal for heating her house. However, her monthly income of $73 does not allow her to make this purchase. Therefore, she hopes to obtain this loan and be able to buy coal. Anipa’s partners: Temirbek, 56, is the father of four children. His wife is unemployed. Temirbek is engaged in breeding cattle and selling milk. He needs a loan to buy a piece of land for his son. His son is married and needs to build his own household. Flyura, 43, is a housewife. She keeps a household and sells milk. Her husband works as a welder. Together they are raising five children. Flyura needs to obtain this loan to be able to attend a funeral of a close relative of hers. Dinara, 38, is a mother of five children. Her husband and elder children support the family by keeping sheep. They have applied for this loan to purchase furniture. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team, Supporters of Kyrgyzstan, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy coal for the rest of the winter season

loans.name: Mujeres De Dios En Progreso 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Sonia is the coordinator of her group Mujeres de Dios en Progreso (Women of God in Progress), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Puerto Plata, an area in the north of the Dominican Republic dependent on a fading tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple, wooden structure as a single mother with her three children.

Sonia is excited to be taking her third loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothing by purchasing a dozen pairs of pants, skirts, brassieres and panties in the main market in Santiago and then selling them for a profit in her village. She will use the profits to invest in her family by changing the walls from wood to cement block, an addition that can pay serious dividends on health and stability in a country where hurricanes are frequent and termites are ravenous. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase pants, skirts, brassiers and panties to sell.

loans.name: Mbonifor

texts.en:
H. is married with six children. He and his entire family live in a house with seven rooms in Ndamukong. This very hard working man joined GHAPE in 2008. H. has encountered some problems in life, such as the death of his father, mother, brother and child in 1992. He was also regrettably unable to continue school, which he loved so much. He became frustrated after he dropped out of school. Thanks to GHAPE, which was created at the time when he most needed it, H. resorted to thinking about going into business. He joined GHAPE and collected his first loan of 37,500 XAF to begin farming and selling firewood.

As a young talented man, even though things are not moving well with his family since his wife has undergone surgery, he is determined to make it in life. With the skills and trainings received from GHAPE, he has been able to improve his living standards. He farms and runs his firewood business for a living. He plans to invest this loan in buying firewood and seedlings along with feed for his piglets, bought with previous loans. H. has been quite successful in the past with his business and is now earning good profit from it due to the fact that he has lots of experience. Part of his profits from this loan will be used to take care of his children, buy necessities for the family and get good medication for them whenever they are sick. The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: buy firewood and seedlings

loans.name: Jumoke

texts.en:
Jumoke is a trader who sells spiritual items like perfume, olive oil, and more. The customers who patronize her business and the people who engage in this business are few, but some people use those items for spiritual exercises. Jumoke has been very successful in her business but she has been able to save little from the profits she makes to assist her husband in taking care of her children.

She hopes to expand her business by stocking her shop with more items. She is requesting NGN 50,000 to purchase more spiritual items to sell to make more profit. 

Jumoke is 42 years old, married and blessed with 3 children. Her youngest child is 7 years old and is doing well in school. She and her family reside in Lagos where she manages her business. She expresses her joy to Kiva lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more spiritual items to sell.

loans.name: Bumi

texts.en:
Bumi is 43 years old, married, and has three children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband is a welder and he also supports their home.
Bumi sells medicines to make a living. She loves her business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow the business to become bigger and stronger, and she hopes to make more profits. Bumi is requesting a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Huuhee

texts.en: Huuhee is 63 years old and lives with her two daughters in Uvs province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Huuhee operates a meat and milk trading business between Mongolian and Tuva Republic of the Russian federation. Huuhee knows the Tuvan language, which is a great advantage for her business. She has been operating her business since 2000 and has built a loyal customer base. Huuhee sells meat, milk and coal from her home. With her earnings, she has been providing money for her family expenses. Huuhee has been planning to expand her business and the number of goods she is able to offer. She is a sociable and hard working person. Huuhee says, “I am working hard to provide better life for my family. ” She is requesting a loan to purchase large amounts of meat and milk at wholesales price for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Biola

texts.en: Biola sells prepared food, drinks and juice in her shop and she has been in the business for the past 6 years. She is happily married with 4 children and she is 46 years of age. She lives in Lagos with her husband, who is a mechanical engineer.  She wants to expand her business in order to increase her profit. She needs a loan of NGN60,000 to purchase more food items and drinks to sell.  She says thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more food items and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Jeneba

texts.en: Jeneba B. trades in various commodities such as cosmetics, provisions, and cigarettes. Her business is located in the eastern part of the city. She is a widow with three children and also has two relatives living with her. Jeneba's business has struggled over the years from the lack of adequate capital. She is therefore asking for a loan in order to buy more goods which will eventually grow her capital. She hopes to use proceeds from the loan to care for her children and save for the future construction of her house. She is a client with very good repayment history.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.es: Eugenia es una trabajadora mujer de 53 años de edad, ella vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos en su casa propia. Ella se dedica desde hace 2 años en la venta y elaboración de ropa, actividad que le gusta mucho, puesto que le resulta muy cómodo realizarlo desde su propia casa. La forma de trabajo de Eugenia consiste en comprar ropa de un reconocido mercado de su ciudad y trasladarlo hasta su casa donde diariamente sale a ofrecer la mercadería a sus vecinas y a sus fieles clientes, quienes le realizan pedidos. Paralelo a este trabajo, también se dedica a confeccionar prendas, gracias a su conocimiento de costura, elaborando variedad de vestidos, blusas, de acuerdo el gusto de los clientes. En un futuro quisiera tener una gran tienda, pero sabe que solo llegará a su meta trabajando muy duro, es por eso que le pone tanto empeño a su trabajo. Es su tercer crédito con MFP y asegura que será muy puntual con todos sus pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará mayor cantidad de mercadería en ropa para así poder aumentar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Eugenia is a hardworking woman who is 53 years old. She lives with her husband and their two children in their own home. For 2 years, she has been making and selling clothing. This is an activity that she enjoys very much, since it is very comfortable for her to do from her own home. Eugenia buys clothing from a well-known market in her city, and takes it to her house where she each day she goes out to offer it for sale to her neighbors and loyal customers, who buy her clothing through orders. In addition to this work, she also makes garments, thanks to her knowledge of dressmaking. She makes a variety of dresses and blouses according to the tastes of her customers. In the future she would like to have a big store, but she knows that she will only achieve this goal if she works very hard. It is for this reason that she puts so much effort into her work. This is her third loan with MFP, and she assures us that she will be very punctual with each of her payments. With the loan she requests, she will buy a greater quantity of clothing so that she can increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise (clothing) to increase her business

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana N., 56, is from the city of Estaka, Dipolog City. She is married and has four adult-aged children.  To make a living, Feliciana owns and operates a store that sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community.  She has been in business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Feliciana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Feliciana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from PMPC to expand her business.  Feliciana is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and for working capital.  This loan will be her 8th from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

------------------------------
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Gisella Natividad

texts.es:
Gisella de 35 años, vive en las Orquídeas de Guayaquil(zona urbana, su originalidad fue que habían muchas flores Orquídeas), ella vende productos Avon (empresa que ayuda a mujeres emprendedoras para que sean vendedoras potenciales). 

Una de las hijas de Gisella al ver la necesidad económica empezó a vender perfumes y cremas en el colegio, cuando Gisella se dio cuenta ella decidió hablar con su hija para que no lo haga mas y Gisella empezó a vender. Poco a poco con esfuerzo ha tenido ingresos para mantener a su familia, vende perfumes, cremas, maquillaje etc. 

Para poder continuar con el negocio de Avon ella necesita comprar con el préstamo cremas, perfumes. En el futuro ella quiere seguir trabajando y comprar un carro para hacer expreso.
texts.en:
Gisella is 35 years old and lives in Orquídeas de Guayaquil, an urban area where many orchids once grew. She sells products manufactured by Avon, a company that helps enterprising women reach their potential as sales representatives.

Due to financial necessity, one of Gisella daughters began selling perfumes and crèmes at school. Gisella could not resist any longer, so she decided to talk with her daughter who gave up her sales so that Gisella could start selling these products. Over time and with effort, she had the income to support her family. She sells perfumes, crèmes, make-up, and other items.

In order to continue her Avon business, Gisella needs a loan to buy crèmes and perfumes. In the future she wants to continue working and buy a car so that she can get around faster.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase crèmes and perfumes

loans.name: Xiomara Group

texts.es:
El grupo Xiomara lo integran tres féminas esforzadas, emprendedoras y trabajadoras originarias de Masaya ciudad de las flores donde su economía se basa en la agricultura. La coordinadora es la señora Rosa Esther M., comerciante de frutas y verduras desde hace cinco años el cual desea mejorar y progresar por ello invertirá el crédito en su negocio.

 Las otras integrantes del grupo son Maribel del Carmen Silva vende frutas y María Magdalena Canon también comercializa perecederos desde hace varios años.
texts.en:
The Xiomara group is composed of three dedicated, enterprising and hard working women who are from Masaya, city of flowers, whose economy is based on agriculture. The group coordinator is Mrs. Rosa Esther M. who has been a fruit and vegetable merchant for five years. She hopes to improve and grow so will invest the loan in her business. The other group members are: Maribel del Carmen Silva who sells fruit and María Magdalena Canon who has also sold perishable items for several years.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy crops.

loans.name: Kiyal

texts.en:
Kiyal J. is a resident of Tup, a nice small town in the Isykul region. Kiyal is 36 and married. She has four daughters, three daughters are at school and the youngest one is not yet. Five years ago with an initial investment of 10000 soms, Kiyal bought a bull and since that moment she started to breed cattle. 

Her husband works in the police and when he has free time he tries to help Kiyal with her activity. Selling some cattle after fattening, Kiyal makes 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase two bulls in order to increase the number of cattle she has. In the future she plans to build a shed and expand her business to have enough money to continue to support her daughters.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase two bulls

loans.name: Ainagul's Group

texts.en:
Ainagul S., leader of the group, is 26 and married. She has two children: her son is four years old and daughter is one year old. Her husband works in Russia. Before her marriage, the women in her husband’s family were selling clothes. After marriage, Ainagul decided to continue her husband’s family business. Now, she is already one year in such business. She started it with initial investment of 5000 soms. Now, her monthly income is 6000 soms. She is applying for a loan in order to increase turnover. On the received loan, she is planning to buy pajamas, jackets, trousers, and female and male underwear to resell. On the profits from her business, she wants to buy a car for her family.

Group members:

Aiymkan E. is treasurer of the group. She is 27 and married. She has two children, five and two years old. Her husband is a taxi driver. With the help of her husband, Aiymkan breeds cattle. In 2004, they decided to hold money in cattle because they considered it safer. They bought two additional livestock for 6000 soms. In six years, they increased number of cattle to seven. Now, cattle breeding bring 3000 soms monthly. They are applying for a loan in order to buy livestock. Then, they will fatten and resell livestock at a higher price. 

Gulmira B. is 32 and married. She has three sons. The elder son is nine, her second son is eight, and they go to school. Her third son is four and he is at home. Her husband is carpenter. Gulimira breeds cattle. She started cattle breeding when she and he husband decided to buy a cow in order to have milk for everyday. Now, she has a cow and a calf and six cattle. Starting cattle breeding with initial investment of 10,000 soms, Gulmira makes 3000 soms monthly. She is already five years in cattle breeding and she plans to continue. So now she is applying for a loan in order to buy three livestock for fattening. Gulmira believes that cattle breeding is a very profitable niche and thus she plans to continue. She plans to build a house, increase livestock numbers and buy a car on the profits.

Umatbek S. is 31 and married. He has two sons of three and two years old. Both of them are at home. He works at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. His wife is a teacher of English language at the local school. Umatbek is applying for a loan in order to buy refrigerator. In the near future, he plans to buy a washing machine for his wife. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase clothing for resale

loans.name: Grimaldina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “NUEVA VICTORIA - CHINCHERO”;  Este banco está situado en el distrito de Chinchero, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco; situado a 45 minutos de la ciudad.

La socia Grimaldina; la socia tiene 83 años de edad y ella es madre soltera y tiene 3 hijos, la socia tiene como principal fuente la agricultura y con ello ella cría animales menores, ella también se dedica a la crianza de chanchos y aves de corral, la socia vende sus animalitos cuando considera que ya están listos para irse de casa, ella es una mujer muy dulce y también tiene una tienda abarrotes que sus hijos le han puesto para que ella ya no esté asistiendo a cultivar sus terrenos, ella tiene una vida más tranquila ahora, ella está en el grupo para buscar un motivo de reunión mensual junto a sus vecinos y amigos, La socia invertirá el monto que solicito para implementar su tienda y comprar aves de corral.

La socia agradece el préstamo mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo estipulado.
texts.en:
The associate belongs to the "NEW VICTORY - CHINCERO" communal bank. This bank is situated in the district of Chinchero, which belongs to the province of Urubamba and department of Cusco; located 45 minutes from the city. The associate, Grimaldina, is 83 years of age and a single mother with 3 children. Agriculture is her main source of income and along with this the raising of small animals. She is also dedicated to the breeding of pigs and poultry. The associate sells her small animals when she considers that they are ready to leave the house. She is a very sweet woman. She also has a convenience store that her children have built for her so that she no longer has to tend her fields. She has a more tranquil life now. She is in the group to find a way to meet monthly with her neighbors and friends. The associate will invest the amount that she requests to supply her store and to buy poultry. The associate is grateful for the loan granted in this way and likewise promises to comply with her loan payments on schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to invest in merchandise for her store and poultry to raise.

loans.name: Carmen Maria

texts.es:
Carmen de 31 años, es vendedora informal de productos Omnilife, vive en una zona periurbana llamada “Paraíso” con caminos de tierra y montañas. 

Hace años atrás ella vendía cosméticos para poder ayudar con los gastos familiares pero como necesitaba mas ingresos una de las amigas la inscribió como vendedora de productos Omnilife, en la actualidad trabaja vendiendo casi toda la línea los productos dirigidos para el malestar de cuerpo, energizantes, vitaminas aunque no tiene horario fijo pero si trabaja sola recorriendo las calles de Paraíso. 

Para seguir con las ventas de estos productos ella quiere comprar mas de estos productos, en el futuro quiere terminar de construir su casa y tener dinero para que su hijo pueda estudiar.
texts.en:
Carmen is 31 years old, and she sells Omnilife products. She lives in a periurban area called “Paraíso” (Paradise), which has dirt roads and mountains. Years ago she started selling cosmetics to be able to help with the family expenses. But, because she needed more income, one of her friends signed her up to sell Omnilife products. She currently works selling almost all of the line of products for physical discomforts, energizers, and vitamins. Even though she does not have a fixed schedule, she works alone traveling the streets of “Paraíso”. In order to continue selling, she wants to buy more of these products. In the future she wants to finish building her house, and she wants to have money so that her child can go to school.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Omnilife products

loans.name: Mariela Katherine

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Charapoto se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Salud y Vida.  Esta localidad se conoce por su cultura tradicional y además por estar a pocos minutos de dos de las  mejores playas de la provincia como son San Jacinto y San Clemente.

La señora Mariela tiene 18 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre hace un año y de esta linda relación tiene un hermoso bebito de 4 meses de nacido. Su marido se dedica al comercio.

Ella vende zapatos de todo tipo, entrega puerta a puerta y deja a crédito, dice que tiene bastantes ventas por las facilidades de pago que da ya que entrega sus productos con una tercera parte del valor y el resto los cobra en dos quincenas. Trabaja de miércoles a domingo, en la actualidad solo trabaja dos horas porque su hijo está muy pequeño. Sus productos los adquiere en un almacén que tiene su suegra en Charapoto.

Este crédito lo va a ocupar para comprar mercadería. Este es tercer ciclo en el Banco Comunal y está muy contenta por la ayuda que ha recibido para salir adelante.
 
Su sueño es tener su casa propia ya que vive en la casa de su mamá.
texts.en:
In the city of Charapoto, the communal bank "Salud y Vida" meets every 15 days.  This area is known for its traditional culture and also for being just a few minutes away from some of the best beaches in the province, such as San Jacinto and San Clemente.

Mariela is 18 years old, and she has been in a common-law marriage for a year which has produced a beautiful 4 month-old baby.  Her husband works as a merchant.

She sells all types of shoes door-to-door, and she extends credit to her customers.  She says that she has substantial sales owing to the ease of payment that she offers.  When she delivers her products she collects a third of the total value, and she collects the rest in 2 installments that are each 2 weeks apart.  She works from Wednesdays to Sundays, and she now only works for 2 hours because her child is very small.  She acquires her products in her mother-in-law's store in Charapoto.

She will use this loan to buy merchandise.  This is her 3rd loan cycle in her communal bank, and she is very pleased because the bank has helped her to get ahead.

loans.use: to buy shoes

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es:
El Sr. Oscar tiene 50 años está casado con la Sra. Delia Jiménez tienen 3 hijos, 1 está casado y los otros 2 estudian medicina y derecho.
El señor trabajaba en un taller de joyería aprendiendo todo sobre trabajos por varios años ganando experiencia y un día decidió independizarse; abrió para su propio taller de joyería, dando trabajo a sus hijos en aquel momento.
 Actualmente se dedica a la venta de joyas independientemente de poseer también una ferretería en su domicilio que administra su señor y solicita el prestamo para la compra de mercaderias para los dos negocios que posee.
En el futuro le gustaría montar un deposito de materiales de construcción por la zona donde se encuentra su domicilio y porque hay una gran demanda.
texts.en:
Sr. Oscar is 50 years old and married to Sra. Delia Jiménez. They have three children, one of whom is married while the other two are studying medicine and law.

Sr. Oscar worked at a jewelry store where he learned every aspect of the business. He spent several years gaining experience until one day he decided to open his own jewelry shop. At the time, he was able to provide jobs for his children.

Oscar currently sells jewelry as an independent merchant, but he also he also manages a hardware store out of his home. He is requesting a loan so that he can purchase merchandise for both businesses.

In the future, he would like to build up an inventory of construction materials in his home to sell in the area because there is great demand for these products.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for his hardware store & his jewelry shop

loans.name: Komlavi

texts.fr: Il est marié et père de 2 enfants. Il a 39 ans. Pour s'occuper de sa famille, il fait la vente de chaussure d'homme. Il exerce cette activité 3 ans deja. Il s'approvisionne en gros au grand marché de lomé et revend en detail au grand marché. Il sollicite ce pret pour accroitre sa marge beneficiaire.
texts.en: Komlavi D. is married and the father of two children. He is 39 years old. To provide for his family, he sells men's shoes. He has been in this business for three years already. He buys his shoes in bulk at the great market in Lomé and retails them at the same market. He applies for this loan to increase his profit margin.

loans.use: To buy men's shoes

loans.name: Basti

texts.en: Basti F. is 50 years old. She sells men's clothes in the Agsu region. She brings the items of clothing from Baku city, which is three hours away from her home. Basti goes to Baku once a month to purchase new stock. She is going to increase her stock by purchasing new seasonal clothes for winter. For this purpose she has applied for a loan of 1,000 AZN. She is promising to repay the loan in a timely manner and AqroInvest has every reason to trust her as she has completed her first loan with Kiva successfully.

loans.use: To purchase new seasonal winter clothes

loans.name: Bertha Ngai

texts.en:
Bertha Ngai N., 45, operates a retail shop and sells household items from Githurai. The area is highly populated so Bertha has many customers. She is married to Charles Kinyua and together they have seven children. The oldest is 25 years old and the last born is 4 years old. Her husband helps support their family.  Bertha was introduced to KADET by existing KADET clients.

Bertha’s retail shop has been in operation for 20 years and her monthly income is 68,800 KES. This loan of 40,000 KES will be her second loan from KADET. The previous loan of 20,000 KES was serviced successfully.

With the loan she intends to add more stock of household goods like sufurias, cups, basins, buckets and jugs which are always in high demand. With the extra profits, Bertha will expand her business and start a supply of household goods to smaller businesses.

Bertha hopes to open a wholesale operation which will supply other towns and employ many sales people.

loans.use: To add more stock of household goods

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine L. is from the village of Ricoro, Gingoog City. She is 26 years old. Josephine is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a business buying and selling bananas & rice per kilogram in the local community.  Josephine has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional bananas & rice to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional bananas & rice to sell

loans.name: Ejidal Group

texts.es:
La señora María Sonia V. Domínguez, vive en la ribera  Morelia Municipio de Coapilla Estado de Chiapas México, vive en unión libre con el señor Federico Pérez Gomes en  donde procreo dos hijas que aun  esta a su responsabilidad quienes son: María Fátima de cuatro años  y la más pequeña Estefanía de dos años.
       El préstamo solidado lo invertirá en la compra de ropas para luego venderlo en la misma localidad, en donde le va bien ya que a obtenido buenos ingresos, como tambien clientes que le compran por mayoreo con esta actividad lleva dos años.
      Por su propia voluntad inicio con esto ya que tambien quiere apoyar asu esposo con los ingresos de su hogar y dándole lo mejor a sus   hijos en educación lo más necesario.
De lo que va obteniendo lo vuelve a invertir en la misma ya que hay ropas que se le terminan muy rápido y su clientela se lo pregunta, para ello no darle una negatividad en no tenerla.
      Su deseo más grande es que con el tiempo logre tener más grande su negocio para que con ello logre sacar adelante a su familia que es lo más importante para ella.
      Su grupo se llama "Ejidal" la razón del nombre es porque donde ellos viven esta cerca una casa ejidal.
      Las personas que forman el grupo son la siguiente:

     María Sonia V. Domínguez: invertirá el préstamo en la compra de ropas para luego venderlo en la  misma localidad.

    Olga Lidia V. Pérez: invertirá el préstamo en la compra de  pollos por reja para luego venderlo en la misma lo calidad.

     Víctor V. Pérez: invertirá el préstamo en la compra refrescos para luego venderlo en la misma localidad.

     Bernardina V. V.: invertirá el préstamo en la compra de roperas para luego venderlo en las comunidades cercanas de su localidad.
texts.en:
María Sonia V. Domínguez lives in Morelia neighborhood, in the town of Coapilla, in the State of Chiapas, Mexico.  She lives with her common-law husband, Federico Pérez Gomes.  They have two daughters who are still in their care: four year-old María Fátima and the youngest, two year-old Estefanía.

María Sonia will invest her loan in buying clothes that she will then sell in her town.  Her business does well and she has made good income.  She also has customers who buy from her wholesale.  She has been in this business for two years.  She started her business on her own initiative since she wanted to support her husband with their household expenses and provide their children with the best possible education, which is the most important thing.

María Sonia re-invests the money she makes in the business since there are clothes that run out very quickly and her customers ask her for them.  She doesn't like to have to disappoint them, telling them that she doesn't have them.  Her biggest dream is to expand her business over time so that, through her business, she can get her family ahead in life which is the most important thing for her.

María Sonia's group is called "Ejidal" (Co-operative).  The reason behind the name is that where the group members live, there is a co-operative building.

The people who make up this group are:

María Sonia V. Domínguez, who will invest her loan in buying clothes to sell in the town

Olga Lidia V. Pérez, who will invest her loan in buying live chickens which she will then sell in the town

Víctor V. Pérez, who will invest his loan in buying soft drinks which he will sell in the town

Bernardina V. V., who will invest her loan in buying wardrobes that she will then sell in neighboring communities

loans.use: To buy clothes such as t-shirts, blouses, pants, etc. to sell in her region

loans.name: El Paraiso Group

texts.es: Maria del Carmen P. es una comerciante de 42 a;os de edad, vive en union libre con el padre de sus dos hijos, y reside en el Barrio Recreo en el municipio de La Union, Olancho. Maria es una persona luchadora, que con mucho esfuerzo a sacado adelante a sus hijos, ella tiene una pulperia en su domicilio y sus hijos le ayudan atenderla. Su horario de atencion es de lunes a domingo desde las 6:00 pm a 7:00 pm. Maria solicita el prestamo para surtir su pulperia de mas y variados productos de la canasta basica. Por los momentos no atraviesa ninguna dificultad. Con el apoyo del prestamo espera seguir obteniendo ganancias y de estas ahorrar un poco para que dentro de poco tiempo pueda tener un negocio mas grande y mas rentable. Su meta es mantener y mejorar su negocio para que cuando ella y su esposo esten ya ancianos no sean una carga economica para sus hijos. Es su vigesimo ciclo en FAMA y ha demostrado responsabilidad y puntualidad en sus pagos.
texts.en: Maria del Carmen P. is a merchant. She is 42 years old and lives with her live-in partner and father of her children in the Recreo neighborhood in the municipality of La Union, Olancho. Maria is a fighter who has painstakingly brought up her children. She has a grocery store in her home and her children help her attend to it. Her schedule is Monday to Sunday from 6:00 am until 7:00 pm. Maria is requesting a loan to stock her grocery store with a greater variety of basic products. Currently, she does not face any difficulties. With the help of this loan she hopes to continue making a profit to be able to save so that eventually she can have a larger and more profitable business. Her goal is to maintain and improve her business so that when she and her husband are older they will not be an economic burden on their children. This is her 20th cycle with field partner FAMA and she has proven to be responsible and punctual with her payments.

loans.use: Purchase groceries to stock her grocery store.

loans.name: Francisco Javier

texts.es:
El Sr. G. Gonzalez, tiene 3 años de laborar en una empresa, de nombre Enacal en el municipio de Granada, actualmente esta acompañado y tiene 3 personas que depende de él.
En estos momentos el señor quiere realizar mejoras de viviendas en su casa de habitación por lo cual esta visitando las oficinas de CEPRODEL para adquirir un préstamo y de esta forma cumplir sus sueños con el mejoramiento de vivienda.
Con esto el señor G., considera que le estará dando una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Mr. G. G. has been employed by a firm called Enacal in the town of Granada for the last three years.  He has a live-in spouse and three people who are dependent on him.

He wants to do some home improvements so is visiting CEPRODEL’s offices to acquire a loan to make his home improvement dream become a reality.

Mr. G. considers that with this he will be providing better quality of life.

loans.use: For home improvement.

loans.name: Stephen Chege

texts.en:
Stephen, age 45, has been in the motorcycle transport business for the last three years. He also has his own rental houses in Naivasha town. He and his wife, Mary Wanjiku, have four children.

He was introduced to KADET Ltd. by his friend and this will be his second loan. He paid off his first loan of Kshs 63,000 promptly and regularly. He plans to use the loan amount to buy materials for building rental houses on his piece of land.

In future, Stephen hopes to buy a car which he will operate as a taxi.

loans.use: To buy materials for building rental houses on his piece of land

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en: Godfrey is a thirty-five-year-old married man with six children, living in his own house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been dealing in produce for the last eight years starting with a capital of 1,000,000 shillings and later expanding to 5,000,000 shillings. His hardship is price fluctuation and little capital and his vision is business expansion, constructing another house, and educating the children. Godfrey needs the loan to buy rice for sale.

loans.use: Buying bags of rice

loans.name: Ronalet

texts.en: Ronalet is a 27-year-old single woman who supports her family by operating an electronic re-loading of phone cards business. She lives in Valladolid, Negros Occidental. Ronalet joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ronalet has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing PHP 24,500 to purchase more electronic loads to sell so that she can continue to save up for future house improvement. Ronalet is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more electronic loads (phone use cards) to sell

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon E., age 52, is a corn farmer. She has planted and harvested corn to offer for sale for over 30 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. Corazon is unmarried.

In 2008, Corazon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Corazon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to plant and raise. 

Corazon is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, for use in her field. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Corazon from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, to use in her field

loans.name: Zaliko

texts.en:
Zaliko K. is 53 years old. He lives in the village of Akura, Telavi District. He lives with his son, daughter-in-law and 1-year-old grandchild. The only source of income for the family is agricultural activities, led by Zaliko. At the moment they have four calves which will be grown and sold in a couple of months. Besides that, the family owns agricultural land with an area of 11 ha. On part of this land is a vineyard. On other parts strawberries, maize, sunflowers and peaches are grown. All harvested grain and fruit are sold locally.  

Now Zaliko plans to sow maize and sunflowers. With the requested loan he will purchase fuel for a tractor, which will till his land, and seeds for maize and sunflowers. Zaliko hopes that he’ll have a good harvest season. Received profit will be invested in livestock – additional calves will be purchased and raised.

loans.use: to purchase fuel for land cultivation and maize and sunflower seeds.

loans.name: Jose Romeo

texts.es:
José, reside en San Rafael Oriente, departamento de San Miguel, se dedica al cultivo de maíz y frijol, vive con sus padres, es soltero y aprendió el oficio con la ayuda de su padre, trabaja todos los días desde hace 8 años.
Actualmente solicita un préstamo para la compra de abonos y fertilizantes, también tratamiento para plagas, esta compra es muy importante ya que sin estos materiales no se puede realizar la siembra.
Para José su principal objetivo es poder continuar cultivando y recibir las mejores cosechas, ya que de su trabajo ayuda a su familia.
texts.en:
José lives in San Rafael Oriente, San Miguel Department.  He grows corn and beans.  He lives with his parents.  He’s single and learned his ccupation from his father.  He’s been working every day for the last 8 years.

He is asking for a loan to buy manure, fertilizer and insecticide.  This purchase is important because without these supplies he cannot carry out his planting.

For José, his main objective is to continue farming and to produce the best harvests because from his work he’s able to help his family.

loans.use: to buy manure, fertilizer and insecticide.

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a ready-to-wear clothing business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for twenty years. She earns more income from food vending.

She is borrowing 15,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional products to sell and to use as working capital for her ready-to-wear clothing business.  She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of the loans from NWTF. 

Analiza dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell and to use as working capital.

loans.name: Anastacio
